CLPP

About

This document describes 'Command line parameters parser' library. Library provides parsing of command line parameters, with callback corresponding functions and, if necessary, checking of parameter's values semantic.


Download

You can download CLPP source code from SourceForge.


License

This library is licensed under LGPL, which means that you can use it for commercial and non-commercial purposes.


Motivation

"Don't reinvent the wheel"

Almost every "console-start" program requires input of some command line parameters, so it handling is very common task. Actually, this handling add up to two tasks:

  • check correctness (in all senses of this word) of inputed parameters,
  • some reaction(s) on it.
CLPP library provides general solution for this tasks. It very easy to use.


"Hello world" example

Simplest example of CLPP using:

 #include <clpp/parser.hpp>

 #include <iostream>
 
 void help() {
     std::cout << "My program, version 1.0. Common usage is..." << std::endl;
     //
 }
 
 int main( int argc, char* argv[] ) {
     clpp::command_line_parameters_parser parser;
     // Register parameter, without value and without any checking...
     parser.add_parameter( "-h", "--help", help );
     try {
         parser.parse( argc, argv );
         // If user inputs '-h' or '--help' in command line, function 'help()' will be called.
     } catch ( const std::exception& exc ) {
         std::cerr << exc.what() << std::endl;
     }
 
     return 0;
 }


Features

  • Header-only (does not require build).
  • Register parameters with two (in Unix-style) or single names.
  • Calls correspond functions, with or without argument.
  • Register unnamed parameters that can be inputed without names.
  • Provides common checks of inputed parameters, like duplication, incorrect, etc.
  • Checking of value's type, like integer or real (defines by type of registered function's argument).
  • Checking of value's semantic, like correct path, etc.
  • Define parameter's necessity.
  • Define parameter's default value.
  • Define another "name-value" separator.

Backward incompatible changes

Since 1.0rc version function check_type() has been removed (it no need anymore). See User's guide for more info.
